pullRequest.body:
If $R$ is a monoid with $0$ and $M$ an additive monoid with an $R$-action, then the set of non-zero smul-divisors of $R$ is a submonoid. for any $r \in R$, $r$ is a non-zero smul-divisors if and only if for any $m\in M$, $r \cdot m = 0$ implies $m = 0$. These elements are also called $M$-regular. They are useful in regular sequences.

---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

please see #7415

bors d+

Thanks!

Do you think it would make sense to change `nonZeroDivisors` to be left-divisors instead of right divisors?

Note: I have pushed an update to the lean toolchain because this PR was on a [buggy version](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Potential.20data.20loss.20from.20.60lake.20clean.60.20with.204.2E2.2E0-rc2.2F3/near/397875701) of the toolchain. **WARNING**: checking out old commits of this PR using v4.2.0-rc2 or v4.2.0-rc3 can cause `lake clean` to delete your mathlib folder! If you need to do so, make sure to delete `lakefile.olean` manually before running any `lake` commands.
bors r+

:lock: Permission denied

Existing reviewers: [click here to make jjaassoonn a reviewer](https://mathlib-bors-ca18eefec4cb.herokuapp.com/repositories/16/add-reviewer/jjaassoonn)

> bors d+
> 
> Thanks!
> 
> Do you think it would make sense to change `nonZeroDivisors` to be left-divisors instead of right divisors?

I just quickly searched `nonZeroDivisors`, it seems that `nonZeroDivisors` is used only in commutative cases, so it should not affect anything if it is changed to right divisors, but it is a non-trivial change to be made.

I have been away for the last month and it seems that the delegation is expired. Can you re-review this and merge it if appropritate please @eric-wieser?

We have a new (self-hosted) bors bot now :) It was [resurrected](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/bors.20going.20away.3F/near/400788923) from its grave and lost all memory about its past life apparently :)

:v: jjaassoonn can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

bors d+

(again)

Sorry for encouraging the scope to grow so large here. Would you mind splitting out everything except the `Mathlib/RingTheory/NonZeroDivisors.lean` change to a new PR (which I'll merge first)? If that's awkward for you, I'm happy to do the git-fu if you open a dummy PR for me to push to.

bors d+

(again)
Does this need `AddMonoid M` instead of `Zero M`? The later lets you re-use this for `nonZeroDivisors`
Indeed, it is sufficient to assume `[Zero M]` only

Style guide says:
```suggestion
  mul_mem' {r₁ r₂} h₁ h₂ m H := h₂ _ <| h₁ _ <| mul_smul r₁ r₂ m ▸ H
```
Please mention this in the module docstring
done

```suggestion
variable {R : Type*} (M : Type*) [MonoidWithZero R] [AddMonoid M] [MulAction R M]
```
when you say reuse `nonZeroDivisors`, do you mean something like this @eric-wieser
No, I meant `(MulOpposite R)⁰[R] = R⁰` which should be true by `rfl` without `comm`
This has bad typing `(MulOpposite R)⁰[R]` has type `Submonoid Rᵐᵒᵖ`
`R⁰[MulOpposite R] = R⁰` I can't get `rfl` on this either
Ah, I think I mean `Submonoid.unop (MulOpposite R)⁰[R]` if that exists

I come up with something like this
```lean

def unop' (x : Submonoid (MulOpposite R)) : Submonoid R where
  carrier := MulOpposite.unop '' x
  mul_mem' := sorry
  one_mem' := sorry

def op' (x : Submonoid R) : Submonoid (MulOpposite R) where
  carrier := MulOpposite.op '' x
  mul_mem' := sorry
  one_mem' := sorry

example : (@unop' R _ ((MulOpposite R)⁰[R]) : Submonoid R) = R⁰ := sorry
example : (@op' R _ R⁰) = (MulOpposite R)⁰[R] := sorry
```
I still don't think the proofs are `rfl` though
They should be defined with the preimage not the image
no idea why right hand side is no longer existent
no idea why right hand side is no longer existent
Can you put these in a new file to match https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3715499a32de6e3036c2bd3db4f94ff4bb0472c7/Mathlib/GroupTheory/Subgroup/MulOpposite.lean?
done
I think this should go in a new `Mathlib/GroupTheory/Submonoid/MulOpposite.lean` file.
(this might be a job for a spin-off PR)
done
Can you add the lemma that says `(opposite H).toSubmonoid = opposite H.toSubmonoid` and similar for `opposite.symm`?
done
I would guess that you can delete this line.
The best I can do is `simpa using mul_mem ha hb`

Does
```suggestion
  mul_mem' {a b} ha hb := x.mul_mem hb ha
```
work? It's what the `Subgroup` file uses.
thanks
I think it would make sense to call this `opEquiv` (since it's the `Equiv` version of `op`), and make the same change to the `Subgroup` versions.
Done. I also changed `oppositeEquiv` to `equivOp` below this definition

```suggestion
    Submonoid.unop ((Rᵐᵒᵖ)⁰[R]) = R⁰ := rfl
```
done
Can you split out the `toFun` and `invFun` field into standalone definitions, to match what you did for `Submonoid`? Or the other way around; the key thing is to use the same approach in both files.
done

```suggestion
#align subgroup.opposite Subgroup.opEquiv
```
I think this should now be `simps`

```suggestion
  mul_mem' ha hb := H.mul_mem hb ha
```

```suggestion
@[to_additive (attr := simp, nolint simpNF)] lemma opposite_toSubmonoid (H : Subgroup G) :
    H.op.toSubmonoid = H.toSubmonoid.op :=
  rfl
```
as I wouldn't expect your spelling to be simp-normal. The name and position of the lemma should also change, as should the `symm` version below.
done

```suggestion
instance (H : Subgroup G) [Encodable H] : Encodable H.op :=
```
and below
I guess it probably makes things less painful downstream if these are `protected`

```suggestion
Use the statement `open scoped nonZeroDivisors nonZeroSMulDivisors` to access this notation in your own
```
